title: Supreme Court stays felling of trees in Mumbai Aarey’s colony
text:
In what can be termed as a victory for green activists, the Supreme Court ordered status quo in the Aarey tree felling case, and ordered the Maharashtra government not to cut any more trees till the next hearing on October 21. The Supreme observed that it “appeared Aarey was a forest at some point of time”, and asked the state government to submit a status report on the number of trees felled so far and the compulsory afforestation by the Mumbai metro.





Yesterday, the court received a letter from a students’ group against the axing of over 2,600 trees for construction of a Mumbai metro car shed at Aarey, and decided to pursue it as public interest litigation (PIL) and constituted a “special bench” to hear the matter.



“A special bench has been constituted to hear the matter tomorrow, October 7 at 10 am on the basis of a letter dated October 6 addressed by Rishav Ranjan with regard to the felling of trees in Aarey forest, Maharashtra which has been registered as public interest litigation,” the court said in a notice.





On Friday, the Bombay High Court rejected a bunch of petitions filed by NGOs and activists against the tree felling at Aarey, post which, the Mumbai Metro Rail Corporation Ltd (MMRCL) started axing trees. Determined to save the city’s lungs, many gathered at the site, and protested against the act. Soon, the gathering increased and Mumbai Police imposed Section 144, thereby banning unlawful assembly.



The protesters have been demanding the relocation of the bus depot, which is a part of the Metro III project.





Several well-known personalities had wished the student activists luck before the hearing of the case. “This is highly condemnable. We support these individuals in helping them get justice. The ruling parties cannot brush this aside till the elections are over,” NCP’s Supriya Sule. Filmmaker Ashoke Pandit had said, “Wishing all the enviornmentalist’s who are fighting to #SaveAarey all the very best for the hearing at #SupremeCourt today. Let’s all together pray for our success in protecting Mother Nature.” Shiv Sena leader Aaditya Thackeray said, “May truth and justice prevail for the ecosystem of Aarey!”
